item.title: A Signal to Industry to Go Green in an Era of Carbon Reduction
item.description: The world economy has a long way to go to break away from the use of coal and oil that fueled progress since the Industrial Revolution.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A coal yard worker in Afghanistan. The climate accord signed in Paris encourages businesses to reduce their reliance on coal.

item.title: The Engineering of Volkswagen’s Aggressive Ambition
item.description: After 20 years under Ferdinand Piëch and Martin Winterkorn, Volkswagen had become a place where subordinates were fearful to contradict their superiors, critics said.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and GRAHAM BOWLEY
item.media:description: A gathering of Volkswagen employees in Wolfsburg, Germany, in 2009.

item.title: Republicans on Campaign Trail Largely Ignore the Climate Deal
item.description: The widely differing reactions to the Paris climate agreement from Democrats and Republicans provided a stark display of the partisan divide.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: THOMAS KAPLAN
item.media:description: President Obama described the Paris climate agreement as “the best chance” to save the planet.

item.title: A Climate Deal, 6 Fateful Years in the Making
item.description: The story of how the deal came together started long before that — in December 2009, with the failure of the last such summit meeting in Copenhagen.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Manila took part in a bicycle ride on Sunday to show support for global efforts to limit climate change.

item.title: Despite Internal Struggles, France Sees Bright Spot as a Successful Host
item.description: Whether France’s success in holding the climate talks will translate into any more lasting gains on other fronts in a country that has struggled this year with terror attacks remains to be seen.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: The Paris Agreement brought a celebratory note in what has been a difficult year for President François Hollande of France.

item.title: Run-In With Turkish Fishing Boat Angers Russian Military
item.description: A Russian warship fired warning shots after the Turkish vessel sailed within 1,600 feet of it, Russia’s Defense Ministry said, increasing tensions between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: In Talks Over Seized U.S. Property, Havana Counters With Own Claim
item.description: Potential compensation for property seized in the Cuban Revolution has excited many. But what if Cuba approaches the talks with a much different claim in mind?
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: Children looked out of a window at the newly reopened United States embassy in August in Havana.

item.title: Afghan Province, Teetering to the Taliban, Draws in Extra U.S. Forces
item.description: A Western diplomat said last week that United States Special Operations forces had been engaged in combat in Helmand for weeks.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.media:description: A member of Afghan security aided a wounded civilian after a suicide bombing last month in besieged Helmand Province.

item.title: Exit Polls in France Show National Front Losing Regional Elections
item.description: After a strong showing in the first round, the latest vote appears to confound expectations that the anti-immigrant party was on the verge of an electoral breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Supporters of the Socialist party waited for results in the Île-de-France region, which includes Paris, on Sunday.

item.title: As Economy Lags, Hugo Chávez’s Movement Fades in Venezuela
item.description: Last week, in a gut blow for the movement known as Chavismo, Venezuela turned raw anger over economic hardship into a landslide victory for the political opposition in crucial elections.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Miguel Gutierrez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexis Duque, 42, works in a liquor store in Barinas, the home state of former President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela. Barinas, which routinely voted for Mr. Chávez and his party, swung to the opposition in the election last week.

item.title: In Milestone, Saudis Elect First Women to Councils
item.description: Though the elections were hailed as a milestone in the conservative kingdom, women will make up less than 1 percent of council members nationwide.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Saudi women cast their votes at a polling station in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, in municipal elections on Saturday.

item.title: Saudi Voters Elect 20 Women Candidates for the First Time
item.description: Saudi voters elected 20 women for local government seats, according to results released to The Associated Press on Sunday, a day after women voted and ran in elections for the first time in the country's history.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Protests Continue in Brazil Against Dilma Rousseff
item.description: Anger over the stuttering economy and political scandals is fueling calls for the ouster of Ms. Rousseff, who has three years to go in her presidential term.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Libyan Factions Urged to Form Unity Government
item.description: Diplomats from 17 nations, fearing further chaos and the expansion of terrorist groups in the country, also called for an immediate cease-fire.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, Foreign Minister Paolo Gentiloni of Italy and Martin Kobler, a United Nations envoy, at a news conference in Rome on Sunday.

item.title: Leaders Move to Convert Paris Climate Pledges Into Action
item.description: Much of the burden for maintaining the momentum of Paris now shifts back to individual countries, and concrete steps for delivering on their pledges.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: A worker at a coal shop in Mumbai, India, waited for customers on Thursday. Rich countries are intent that India not get stuck on a coal-dependent development path.

item.title: Saudi Elections Are First to Include Women as Voters and Candidates
item.description: The elections for members of local councils across the kingdom marked the first time that women were able to participate — as both voters and candidates.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Women left a polling place in Riyadh on Saturday. The municipal elections were the first time that women were able to vote.

item.title: Sunni Militants Claim Deadly Attack at Market in Pakistan
item.description: The militants said the bombing, which killed at least 22, was revenge against Shiites supporting President Bashar al-Assad in the Syrian civil war.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, a banned Sunni extremist group, claimed responsibility for the attack in the town of Parachinar, Pakistan. Some of the injured were transported from the scene on Sunday.

item.title: By Buying Paper, Alibaba Seeks to Polish China’s Image
item.description: Some question how The South China Morning Post, based in Hong Kong, can stay editorially independent if its new owners explicitly seek to improve China’s image.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The Alibaba Group wants to use The South China Morning Post to reshape coverage of China. A newsstand in Hong Kong bore the logo of the newspaper that Alibaba purchased last week.

item.title: Iraqi’s Oregon Jackpot Raises Questions on Lottery Sales
item.description: The state’s director said that the winner did nothing wrong, but that an investigation was continuing into whether international ticket sales are entirely legal.
item.dc:creator: KIRK JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Meg Roussos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jack Pedro, an owner of Binky's, a deli in Bend, Ore. A lottery ticket worth $6.4 million was bought there on behalf of an international online service.

item.title: Nations Approve Landmark Climate Accord in Paris
item.description: The deal, which required unanimous approval by delegates from around the world, will for the first time commit nearly every country to lowering greenhouse gas emissions.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Representatives of the “high-ambition coalition,” including Foreign Minister Tony de Brum of the Marshall Islands, left, wore lapel pins made of dried coconut fronds, a symbol of Mr. de Brum's country.
